tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving compressor power, mass flow rate, and impeller speed to find the impeller diameter. It requires understanding of compressor work and velocity triangles, making it a multi-concept integration and multi-step reasoning problem.

answer_validation.correct_answer: 0.46 m (any value in the official range 0.40 to 0.50 m)
answer_validation.reasoning: Given shaft power and mass flow rate, the specific work is $w = P/\dot{m}$. For a centrifugal compressor with no slip and no impeller losses, the Euler equation gives $w = U_2 c_{w2}$ and with no slip $c_{w2} = U_2$, so $w = U_2^2$. Thus $U_2 = \sqrt{w}$. Using $P = 1800\,\text{kW}$ and $\dot{m} = 10\,\text{kg/s}$, $w = 180{,}000\,\text{J/kg}$, so $U_2 = \sqrt{180{,}000} \approx 424.3\,\text{m/s}$. The impeller tip speed is also $U_2 = \omega r_2 = \omega D_2/2$. With $\omega = 1900\,\text{rad/s}$, $D_2 = 2U_2/\omega = 2\times 424.3/1900 \approx 0.447\,\text{m}$. This lies within the official answer range 0.40 to 0.50 m, so the key is consistent.

step_by_step: Identify given data: shaft power $P = 1800\,\text{kW} = 1.8\times 10^6\,\text{W}$, mass flow rate $\dot{m} = 10\,\text{kg/s}$, angular speed $\omega = 1900\,\text{rad/s}$, no slip, no impeller losses.
Compute specific work input to the air: $w = P/\dot{m} = 1.8\times 10^6 / 10 = 1.8\times 10^5\,\text{J/kg}$.

Use Euler turbomachinery equation for compressor with no inlet whirl and no losses: $w = U_2 c_{w2} - U_1 c_{w1}$. With usual assumption $c_{w1} \approx 0$ and no slip, $c_{w2} = U_2$, so $w = U_2^2$.
Relate tip speed to diameter using $U_2 = \omega r_2 = \omega D_2/2$. Thus $D_2 = 2U_2/\omega = 2\times 424.3/1900 \approx 0.447\,\text{m}$.
Round to two decimal places: $D_2 \approx 0.45\,\text{m}$, which is within the official acceptable range 0.40 to 0.50 m.

topic.name: Centrifugal compressors and Euler turbomachinery equation
topic.syllabus_ref: Propulsion -> Gas turbine engines and components -> Compressors

concepts.name: Relationship between tip speed and rotational speed
Power and mass flow rate relation

essential: Basic turbomachinery kinematics (blade speed, radius, angular velocity)
Concept of specific work (work per unit mass)
Unit consistency between kW, W, J/kg, and m/s
Understanding of slip and no-slip idealization in centrifugal compressors
helpful: Distinction between shaft power and fluid power
Physical meaning of whirl (tangential) velocity component

Main Concept: requires: Relationship between angular speed and tip speed
enables: Design of compressor diameter for given power and speed
enables: Performance estimation and scaling of centrifugal compressors

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling that with no slip and negligible inlet whirl, specific work equals $U_2^2$
Students may confuse angular speed in rad/s with rotational speed in rpm
Careful unit handling is needed when converting kW to W

textbook_references.author: V. Ganesan
textbook_references.section: Key Concepts and Worked Examples on Slip Factor and Work Input
textbook_references.text_snippet: The slip factor (\mu) is the ratio of the actual outlet whirl velocity to the impeller tip speed. For an ideal energy transfer process, the air should exit the impeller with a tangential (whirl) component of absolute velocity that is equal to the impeller's tip speed. This condition (V_w2 = U_2) corresponds to maximum theoretical work input per unit mass according to the Euler turbomachinery equation.

textbook_references.author: H. Cohen, G.F.C. Rogers, H.I.H. Saravanamuttoo

video_references.topic_covered: Euler equation for turbomachines and application to centrifugal compressors

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Power and mass flow rate \rightarrow Specific work \rightarrow Euler equation with no slip \rightarrow Tip speed \rightarrow Diameter from angular speed
key_insights: With no slip and negligible inlet whirl, the Euler work reduces to $w = U_2^2$.
Knowing angular speed directly in rad/s avoids rpm-to-rad/s conversion errors.
Once tip speed is known, diameter follows linearly from $U_2 = \omega D_2/2$.

formulas_principles.name: Specific work from power and mass flow
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies when P is the power transferred to the fluid and \dot{m} is the mass flow rate through the compressor
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute work per unit mass from given shaft power and mass flow rate

formulas_principles.name: Euler turbomachinery equation
formulas_principles.conditions: Steady, one-dimensional flow through a turbomachine stage
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates specific work to blade speed and whirl components at inlet and exit

formulas_principles.name: Specific work for ideal centrifugal compressor with no slip
formulas_principles.conditions: No slip so $c_{w2} = U_2$ and negligible inlet whirl so $c_{w1} \approx 0$
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation used to find tip speed from required specific work

formulas_principles.name: Tip speed-angular speed relation
formulas_principles.conditions: Rigid body rotation, r_2 is impeller outer radius
formulas_principles.relevance: Connects mechanical rotational speed to fluid tangential speed at the impeller tip

industry_examples: Sizing the impeller of an auxiliary power unit (APU) centrifugal compressor to deliver required bleed air at a given shaft speed.
Preliminary design of small turbojet or turboshaft engines where a single-stage centrifugal compressor is used and shaft speed limits are imposed by mechanical stresses.
specific_systems: Small turbojet engines used in UAVs often use single-stage centrifugal compressors whose diameter is set from power and speed constraints.
APUs on commercial airliners (e.g., Boeing 737 APU) use centrifugal compressors where tip speed and diameter are tightly constrained by stress and efficiency.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Correctly relating power, mass flow, and impeller diameter ensures that the compressor can achieve the desired pressure ratio without exceeding material stress limits or causing excessive tip Mach numbers, which directly affects engine reliability and efficiency.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using $w = U_2 c_{w2}$ but then assuming $c_{w2}$ is unknown and introducing extra assumptions instead of recognizing that no slip implies $c_{w2} = U_2$.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember the general Euler equation but forget the simplification under the no-slip idealization.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Explicitly write the condition 'no slip $\Rightarrow c_{w2} = U_2$' before starting calculations and simplify the Euler equation accordingly.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to unnecessary unknowns and possibly incorrect or unsolvable equations.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to convert power from kW to W, using 1800 instead of $1.8\times 10^6$ in the specific work calculation.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing through unit conversions under exam pressure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write units explicitly in intermediate steps and check that J/kg results from W divided by kg/s.
common_mistakes.consequence: Specific work becomes 1000 times smaller, giving tip speeds and diameters off by a factor of about 30.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using $U_2 = \pi D_2 N/60$ with $N$ incorrectly taken as 1900 (thinking it is rpm) instead of using $U_2 = \omega D_2/2$ with $\omega$ in rad/s.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between angular speed in rad/s and rotational speed in rpm.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Check the dimension: if the problem gives rad/s, use $U = \omega r$; if rpm, convert to rad/s or use the $\pi D N/60$ form consistently.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect diameter, often outside the accepted range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Including inlet whirl term $U_1 c_{w1}$ even though the problem does not provide inlet whirl and standard assumption is $c_{w1} \approx 0$.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Overcomplicating the problem by using the most general form of the equation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall that for many compressor design problems, inlet flow is taken as purely axial (no whirl) unless stated otherwise.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and may force unjustified assumptions about inlet conditions.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: No slip, no whirl in: work is U-square in
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that with no slip and negligible inlet whirl, $w = U_2^2$
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when simplifying Euler equation for ideal centrifugal compressor problems.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Power over mass gives work per mass
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever converting from shaft power and mass flow to specific work.

flashcards.front: What is the Euler turbomachinery equation for specific work in terms of blade speed and whirl components?
In an ideal centrifugal compressor with no slip and negligible inlet whirl, what does the Euler equation reduce to?
flashcards.back: With $c_{w1} \approx 0$ and $c_{w2} = U_2$, the equation becomes $w = U_2^2$.

flashcards.front: Define slip factor in a centrifugal compressor and its ideal value.
flashcards.back: Slip factor $\mu$ is the ratio of actual outlet whirl velocity to ideal (blade speed) whirl velocity: $\mu = c_{w2,\text{actual}}/U_2$. Ideal case: $\mu = 1$ (no slip).

flashcards.front: How is impeller tip speed $U_2$ related to angular speed $\omega$ and diameter $D_2$?
You are given power in kW and mass flow in kg/s. What must you do before computing specific work $w$?
flashcards.back: Convert power from kW to W (multiply by 1000) so that $w = P/\dot{m}$ is in J/kg.

real_world_context.application: Preliminary sizing of centrifugal compressor impellers in gas turbine engines
real_world_context.industry_example: In a small turboshaft engine for a helicopter, designers may know required compressor power (e.g., 2 MW) and shaft speed (e.g., 2000 rad/s). Using relations like $w = U_2^2$ and $U_2 = \omega D_2/2$, they estimate impeller diameter to keep tip Mach number and stresses within limits.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect diameter selection can lead to excessive tip speeds, causing high stresses, blade failure, or poor efficiency due to high Mach number effects.

real_world_context.application: Retrofit and performance upgrades of existing centrifugal compressors in process plants
real_world_context.industry_example: Chemical plants sometimes replace impellers to increase throughput. Engineers must ensure the new impeller diameter and speed combination delivers the required work without exceeding motor power or mechanical limits.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Overloading the drive motor or exceeding design stresses can cause costly downtime and safety hazards.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Identify it as a direct application of Euler equation with no slip. Quickly compute specific work from power and mass flow, then use $w = U_2^2$ and $U_2 = \omega D_2/2$. Minimal algebra, so it should take under 3 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, estimate that typical centrifugal compressor tip speeds are 350–450 m/s and use $D_2 \approx 2U_2/\omega$ with $\omega \approx 2000$ rad/s to get a diameter around 0.4–0.5 m.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2–3 minutes. Do unit checks once; avoid re-deriving Euler equation—recall the simplified form directly.

search_keywords: centrifugal compressor slip factor no slip
impeller tip speed and diameter relation
V Ganesan Gas Turbines centrifugal compressor example
GATE AE centrifugal compressor numerical problem

alternative_methods.name: Use rpm-based blade speed relation
alternative_methods.description: If the problem had given rotational speed in rpm instead of rad/s, you could use $U_2 = \pi D_2 N/60$ to relate tip speed and diameter. The rest of the method is the same: compute specific work, find $U_2$ from $w = U_2^2$, then solve for $D_2$.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Familiar to many students used to rpm. Cons: Requires careful unit conversion from rpm to rad/s or consistent use of the $\pi D N/60$ formula, which can introduce errors.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When angular speed is given in rpm and you are more comfortable with the $\pi D N/60$ relation.

connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: Specific work in compressors is directly related to stagnation temperature rise via $w = c_p \Delta T_0$, linking mechanical design to thermodynamic performance.
connections_to_other_subjects.Strength of Materials: Tip speed and diameter determine centrifugal stresses in the impeller, requiring stress analysis to ensure safe operation.
connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: Velocity triangles and whirl components are rooted in conservation of angular momentum and fluid kinematics.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Compressor performance influences thrust and specific fuel consumption, affecting aircraft performance calculations.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of Euler turbomachinery equation from conservation of angular momentum
Slip factor correlations (Stodola, Wiesner) and their impact on compressor design
Effect of tip Mach number and Reynolds number on centrifugal compressor efficiency
Multi-stage compressor design and matching of stages for desired overall pressure ratio

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Gas turbine engines; axial and centrifugal compressors; turbines; performance characteristics
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely integrates turbomachinery theory (Euler equation) with simple numerical design, matching the expected depth for GATE AE propulsion.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks from Ganesan's 'Gas Turbines' discussed centrifugal compressor concepts such as slip factor, Euler equation, and examples relating work input to tip speed. While not the exact problem, they provided the same core relations (e.g., $w = U_2^2$ for ideal no-slip case) and context for this calculation. No direct video RAG was provided, but generic NPTEL references were added from model knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Given a required pressure ratio and isentropic efficiency, compute the impeller diameter using slip factor and power input factor.
For a centrifugal compressor with known diameter and speed, determine the maximum mass flow rate before choking at the impeller eye.
Include non-zero inlet whirl due to prewhirl vanes and ask students to compute required impeller diameter for a given power.
Ask for the slip factor given measured power, diameter, speed, and mass flow rate, combining experimental data with theory.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A centrifugal compressor requires 1800 kW of power to compress 10 kg/s of air. Consider the whirl velocity component is equal to the impeller speed (ie., no slip) and no losses in the impeller. If the impeller has to rotate at 1900 rad/s, the diameter of the impeller is to be ________ m (in two decimal place).
